None
text:
This is the BEST bruschetta recipe I've ever tried, and I've tried a bunch of them! Here are a few tips from someone who has made this recipe at least a dozen times: 1) Once, I couldn't find sun-dried tomatoes packed in oil and used the dry kind. Perhaps it was my imagination, but I think I lost some of that distinctive sun-dried tomato flavor. 2) The recipe suggests that you could use dried basil if you're in a pinch. That's true, but use it ONLY if you're in pinch! Fresh basil (I chiffonade mine) is part of what makes this recipe so absolutely delicious. 3) The recipe calls for shredded cheese, but I like to buy bulk mozzarella and slice it into pieces that are about 1/8" thick, and that are sized to fit onto the bruschetta. That keeps your cheese from falling off the sides, and it creates a nice "blanketing" effect over your tomato mixture that keeps it from falling off when you're eating it. Enjoy!

text:
Delicious. My friends felt there was something missing and next time I plan on adding some fresh cut Oregano and doubling the garlic. I also plan on cutting the amount of olive oil used in half to only 1/8 cup. From the suggestions of previous reviewers I decided to brush olive oil onto the bread, broil it for a couple minutes, then add the topping. The cutting of the tomatoes did take a bit of time and I think substituting a couple cans of diced tomatoes would be fine. Just be sure to use FRESH herbs! I will be adding this receipe to my regular rotation.

text:
Simply the best Bruschetta I have ever made!  It got rave reviews from everyone over the holidays.  I would definitely suggest letting it marinate over night - the longer the better.  I also took someone's suggestion to put the cheese on the bread and bake it first - then everyone can put on their own amount of bruschetta.  Everyone agreed that was the better way to go.  This really is easy to make - I also definitely suggest using fresh basil and buying the bread the day you are serving it as well.

text:
Love this recipe.  Have made it many times since finding it online...  There is a reason this recipe lists roma/ plum tomatoes as the tomato of choice.  They are meatier than a beefsteak, early girl, or some of the other varietals available.  Using romas will eliminate some of the wateriness that other reviewers have mentioned.  If you have the opportunity to make this a day ahead, it gives the flavors a chance to marry and allows the garlic to mellow somewhat ~ so MUCH better!  Absolutely great as it is, but decided to try adding a smidgen of anchovy paste to it on the third time.  It sent it over the edge from outstanding to sublime!!!   Thanks so MUCH for this recipe!!!

text:
WOW...these were AWESOME!!  I've never made tomato bruschetta before and these I would definitely make again.  Tried them out on family this weekend before I take it to a party next week.  Got rave reviews!  These are the things I changed: 1) Used 2 cans of petite diced tomatoes rather than cutting up tomatoes.  (Tasted great and much easier!) 2) Our grocery store didn't have sun-dried tomatoes so I used sun-dried tomato spread...worked great!  3)Definitely brush the bread slices w/olive oil first and throw in oven for 5 min at 400 degrees. Bread was not at all soggy, yet not too hard either 4) Use both parmesan (fresh) and mozzarella on top.  5) put back in 400 degree oven for @5 min till cheese melts.  Very good stuff!!

text:
I would not reduce the amount of balsamic vinegar or garlic - tasted great the way it was!! Got lots of raves at the party I attended. Very simple to make, but people will think you slaved over it! 

Instead of 6 tomatoes, I used 5, and I substituted dried basil for fresh, and served the tomato mixture cold, with no mozzerella on the broiled baguette slices. Before I broiled the baguette slices, I also spread a bit of garlic butter onto the bread. 

Definitely will be making this again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very very nice recipe. I did change it a bit to better suit our preferences. Plum tomatoes are the best but if you don't have that you can use regular. Canned would work but be sure to drain it well or your bread will get very soggy. I prefer to omit the sun dried tomatoes and go all fresh. I use 2 cloves of garlic instead of 3. We are garlic lovers but I don't want too much garlic taste. I find the flavours even out better for us with just 2 cloves. I omit the balsamic vinegar. Not big fans of it. For sure fresh basil. Always go fresh when you can. Instead of mozzarella cheese I use goat cheese. Adds a wonderful unique flavour. Also, I cut the baguette into thinner slices, maybe 1/4 inch. It's easier to bite and chew when the pieces are not as thick. Again, it depends on your preferences. Next time I think I will double the batch. It disappears soooo fast.

country:
None
text:
This is now my go-to bruschetta recipe!
It's sooo easy and it's impressive to serve.

I don't like putting the mozzarella on top, I feel like it looks cheap, almost like pizza.  
I like serving it looking a little more refined and up-scale.
I take sliced mozzarella and cut it into small pieces to fit on my bread slices.
After toasting the bread, then I toast it with the small piece of cheese on it.  THEN I add the tomato mixture.  It seems to hold the tomato well (doesn't fall off at all) and it looks impressive.

Sometimes I top it off with some shaved Parmigiano-Reggiano, and it makes it look just that much more impressive, and adds a little something.  :)

I love bruschetta......and this recipe is by far the BEST recipe I have ever made or tasted.  I served this on Christmas Eve and it went within minutes and I had made 2 batches.  I made it ahead of time and left it in the fridge overnight for optimal flavor.  I toasted my bread with garlic butter and parmesan seperately and put the (warm) toasts around the edge of the platter with the (cold) bruschetta in the middle.  I have never had more compliments on a dish EVER!  Will be a staple item on our Christmas Eve Appetizer Buffet table.  THANKS SO MUCH!

text:
I made this recipe as written, except for the baguette and Mozzarella (I was looking for a flavorful, low cal blend to add to cabbage to get the bruschetta flavor...).  I really felt like it was missing something besides the bread and cheese.  If I used shredded Mozzarella, it would get soggy...  Well, I added about 3/4 tsp of grated Parmesan, and that gave it the flavor it was missing...  and took it from a good quality recipe to a restaurant quality (or better!).  It's funny how a simple ingredient can be the item that brings it all together...  I'd suggest trying it both ways, and seeing if you would agree.  With the addition of the Parm, I give it 5 stars, but as written, 4 stars.  But it's a very good base.

text:
I made this for a party I hosted and every single guest asked for the recipe.  I didn't bother with toasting the bread or the mozzarella cheese though since I didn't have the time and it was less hassle this way and it was still fantastic.  I did however use fresh basil and even put in a handful extra just because I like basil so much.  I have to say that I think the sun-dried tomatoes added something special to it. I also made it a day before I served it and drained off the juice prior to serving.  I think that helped make it not making the bread too soggy.  

This was the BEST tomato bruschetta I've ever had.  A definite keeper.

text:
Mmm Mmm good! This is almost exactly how we always make it, just eyeballing the amounts. What's different about this is the garlic - we just never added it, never thought it needed anything else, but with the addition of garlic (2 cloves) it was just that much better! Also, we serve over lightly toasted (both sides) baguette slices & add small chunks of fresh mozzarella to the tomato mixture & serve as a refreshing cold appetizer/salad. Or at other times we cut the tomatoes into larger chunks & pile it all up on a toasted bread that's been rubbed with raw garlic & topped with mozzarella and/or parmesan & place under the broiler prior to piling the tomato mixture on top. The melted mozzarella layer helps keep the btread from getting soggy. I love easy recipes like this that are also versatile & always impressive!

text:
This was fantastic. I cut the recipe in half because it was just my husband and I. I had one and he had like 8 helping. AMAZING. The only substitutions I made was white Balsamic because I didnt want it to change the color and it is a little more mild. Also when I put the bread in the oven to toast I brushed with a little Olive oil and sprinkled the bread with a tiny bit of salt and pepper. When I topped  the tomato mixture I used a combo of Parm/Romano. Fantastic. Im sure it would be wonderful as written as well.

text:
The BEST bruschetta!  I made a couple of changes though.  Instead of the tomatoes packed in oil, I found canned tomatoes that were fire roasted with a hint of garlic (you can find these in any supermarket) and I used 1/2 cup of those.  Then, I broiled the slices of bread for 1 minute on both sides.  It helps with it being a bit soggy if you want a crispier bruschetta.  I'm definitely keeping this recipe!

O.M.G! SOOOOO delicious!! Other than doubling the recipe for a big party I followed the recipe for the tomatoe mixture almost exactly. The only thing I changed was the olive oil. I still can't believe it but I ran out of the olive oil so in a last minute pinch I used the left over oil from my sun-dried tomatoes. I figure t only added more yummy flavor than the olive oil alone. As far as the rest of the recipe goes I used fresh mozzarella cheese in place of the shredded and I rubbed garlic on the french bread slices after toasting them under the broiler.  I will use this recipe from here on out! There is no other bruschetta recipe in my opinion!

text:
I loved this bruchetta recipe! I had my oven on 375 for another recipe & toasted my bread first, until crisp (not browned)with no added oil. Then I baked them again at that temp. with the topping on until the cheese melted. This made the bruchetta stay crunchy all evening. I would also recommend buying 2 baguttes. I ended up having enough topping for 1 1/2 baguette slices. Oh, and I used 2 cans of diced tomatoes for the fresh. It really helps the tomatoes stay on the bruchetta & makes this recipe even quicker to make!

None
text:
This is excellent! I used fresh basil and I'm telling you--dont bother making this unless you use fresh basil. It totally makes the dish. Instead of chopping all the tomatoes, I used my food processor and 'pulsed' it all together. It makes it a coarse, relish-like consistency. Also let this sit for several hours after making it because it truly gets better with age. I kept dipping into it with crackers before dinner because it was so addicting.  My husband loved it--a total keeper!

None
text:
This recipe is the best for parties and get togethers.  I make it the true italian way.  I just broil the bread slices ahead of time for a minute or two on each side, then cut a garlic clove in half and rub it over one side of each piece.  Then I just set out the toasted peices and a bowl of the tomato mixture.  There is no need to heat it up.  I also mix one cup of parmesan cheese in with the mixture instead of mozerella.  delicious and so easy!

text:
At least 5 stars, or more. This was perfect. I used just dry sundried tomatoes, $5 for the ones in oil was alittle much. I also brushed the bread with olive oil and toasted it. Then put cheese on and broiled that, so people could top it with as much or as little bruschetta as they wanted. It took about 1 1/2 loafs of bread to use all the bruschetta, but it was heavenly. I will make this for every event from here on out. Thank you!

region:

None
text:
I too didn't have the sun dried tomatoes packed in oil either but I had dried ones and just soaked them in water for a few minutes to soften them. Also, after I mixed all the ingredients together, I let it sit for a few hours to let the flavors marinate together.  This recipe can be made ahead of time and just put on the bread and broiled in a couple of minutes.  I think it helped a bunch.  I found that the amount of this recipe needed to be doubled to fill a whole baguette.  Maybe I cut my bread to thin or put too much on my bread, but I would double it next time.  This was a hit at my most recent party and I will definitely make this again.

text:
This was amazing, but the freshness of the basil/tomatoes definately made this what it was! I used 1/2 teaspoon balsamic vinegar(due to high sulfates and Im pregnant)instead of what was called for, and I didnt have sun-dried tomatoes so I used fresh organic cherry tomatoes with organic roma tomatoes and a little extra olive oil(just a tad). I also reduced the garlic to 1 clove(not a big garlic fan), and added about 1/4 Cup of finely diced bell peppers maybe a little less. I used sea salt and added parsley. This was great and I couldnt find baguetts so I just used toasted wheat bread and it was great. i will try a thicker bread next time, cuz it did make my bread soggy, but it was still great. My husband even loved it and he is not a fan of store bought tomatoes at all.

I converted recipe to serve 8. As a side dish it would have served 3 generously, and as an appetizer 4 perfectly. I used canned diced tomatoes, drained well. Fresh tomatoes would have been perfect. Used fresh basil as suggested in other reviews. Definitely the way to go. 5 stars for flavor and simplicity. The sun dried tomatoes packed in oil was enormous in cost at $7.60 USD for the jar. The expense is a bit much to me for a casual occasion (totalled nearly $15.00 USD for all non-standard ingreds.) For a dinner party, other formality or special occasion I'd make it again.  Not too happy with the expense though. The recipe is great. FH loved it.

The whole family loved this one. There was absolutely nothing left after dinner when I made these - and yes I served the recipe as a light entree with sides of broccoli and cottage cheese.

With the first bite, even the 11 year old loved this recipe. And they look good too.

Regrettably, I didn't have fresh basil on hand, so I used dried. Fresh would have been a great addition and I will do that next time.

The fresh and sundried tomatoes are a nice pairing. With the sundried tomatoes, the flavor is much more substantial.

I will definitely make this again, most likely tomorrow!

Bets bruschetta recipe I have ever had!  This is not too garlicky or contain onions, but it is sooooo flavorful.  Like other reviewers, we used half the oil (since the sun dried tomoatoes are packed in oil, it adds plenty of oil). Great recipe! I was throwing a party in a big hurry--right after two exams.  I had limited time and limited energy.  I prefer to use fresh ingredients, but I had to cheat and use Recipe Ready! Petite Diced Tomatoes from a can.  I also used sundried tomatoes that I soaked in olive oil overnight, rather than the kind from a jar (which always have added spices).  Instead of mozzarella, I used a grated blend of Parmesan, Romano, and Asiago cheeses, simply because that was what I had.  Even without using fresh ingredients, this was a hit. My guests could not get enough, AND it was quick and easy to prepare.

This stuff is outstanding!  I used it for an hors d'oeurves party at our apartment complex and couldn't keep the platter full!  For anyone from the Omaha area, this recips tastes very similar to the tomato/basil condiment served at Lo Sole Mio.  This recipe does make a lot, so be sure to have several baguettes on hand--three wasn't enough for us.  I used the leftover tomato mix in a pasta dish.  I'm considering keeping this mixture on hand at all times as a great addition to pastas and salads.  Even my friends who don't like tomatoes loved this recipe.

text:
Served at an outside party that lasted for hours, so these suggestions are based on ease and practicality. Have a loaf of baguette bread cut by the bakery dept at the grocery store into "bruschetta slices."  Broil the mozzarella cheese (be sure to get the kind that comes in a ball -- it tastes better and does make a difference) in the oven on top of the bread.  Leave a bowl of the tomato mixture for people to serve themselves. At a party it keeps the bread from getting soggy.  ;)  Tasty recipe!!!

userID:

Display Name:
Eileen614
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/770760.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Hey Laurie, thank you for this amazing recipe. I, probably like the rest of the reviewers, have made bruschetta on many occasions. I was browsing through recipes to change mine up a bit and found your recipe.  I NEVER thought of putting sun dried in with the fresh tomatoes and I can't believe I didn't because I love the taste of both. This takes Bruschetta to the gourmet level. The only changes I made were using "tomatoes on the vine" because I didn't have any romas, and subbing white balsamic for regular balsamic. This avoided the "brownish tint" one reviewer commented on. I also added some fresh oregano as I love the flavor with tomatoes and basil. Fresh basil definitely is a must with this recipe. I was thinking in a pinch if I didn't have fresh basil on hand I could always add a spoonful of homemade pesto to the tomatoes instead. I also toasted my bread in advance dipping my brush into the jar of sun dried tomatoes and using that oil instead of olive oil or butter. I also sprinkled fresh parm on the bread before toasting. The best thing about this recipe is that you can do so many things with it. I have made it as suggested with fresh mozzarella toasted on the bread, but this time of year, its all about being cool.  I made this today with fresh mozzarella diced into little pieces and chilled with the tomato mix.   I toasted baguettes & served the tomatoes on the side EVERY PERSON ASKED ME FOR THE RECIPE!  That really says something! Thank you again Laurie...

text:
Very tasty....  I am not big on Bruschetta but my husband loves it, so I am learning to like it. The sundried tomatoes drew me to this recipe.  I diced to tomatoes nice and small.  Letting it sit over night or at least a couple hours helps the flavors marry!  I lightly brown both sides of my baguette slices.  Do not use 2% Mozzerella as it does not like to melt!!!  I have to say I even liked it better the second night.  My husband of course LOVES it!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the BEST bruschetta I have ever tasted!  I have ordered bruschetta many times in restaurants and this recipe beats them all. The topping is so moist, flavorful and succulent.  It was a big hit at our New Years Eve party.  I made some slight "tweakings" to make it better.  First, I used my bread machine to make homemade bread (I used the dough setting and then shaped the dough into a long, thin baguette and baked in the oven).  I also marinated the topping for a few hours instead of 10 minutes as directed.  Finally, I brushed the bread slices with a little olive oil before broiling for extra flavor and texture.  Otherwise, I did not change the essential recipe.  This recipe is one of my new favorites and I know I will make it again and again.

text:
This is a great recipe-- I don't eat garlic so I didn't use that, but I have a great suggestion that makes this easy and great for parties.  Make this with out the bread in a shallow baking dish.  Toast your bread and set it in a basket beside the bruschetta that way it doesn't take up as much room and the bread doesn't get soggy you can pop it in the microwave whenever you need to warm it up.....

text:
I have made this many times over the past couple of years and it is always a hit.  The only changes I've made are to use only 4-5 romas and I like the one reviewers idea of using sliced mozzarella on top; it does help to keep it all from sliding off.  Tonight I used portobello mushrooms instead of the bread:  just rubbed them with a little EVOO and baked for about 5 minutes (at 425), added the bruschetta and baked 5 more minutes, topped with mozzarella and baked just til the the cheese melted.  Delicioso!!!

text:
This is fabulous!  I made this 3 times since discovering two weeks ago.  Read other comments, and used only 2 Tablespoons of olive oil.  Highly recommend using a good quality balsamic vinegar and use fresh garlic, as using a bargain brand balsamic (Walmart) and preminced garlic from a jar (Costco), while still good, did not yield the fabulous flavor.  Everyone that tasted this has asked immediately for the recipe!  Thank goodness I can refer them to Allrecipes website!

We did not like the sun-dried tomatoes in this recipe.  It didn't have enough of a vinegar flavor, and had too much oil.  We put leftovers in the refrigerator and my husband liked it better the second day.  Next time I would leave out the sun-dried tomatoes, decrease oil to 3 tbsp, increase vinegar to 3 tbsp, and add scallions.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great base recipe. I used it for a dinner party and everyone loved it! I did make a few small changes which were for the better (rather than a mini-pizza style bruschetta). 

Changes:
3 tbsp balsamic vinegar
5 Roma + 1 Big Boy tomato
4oz crumbled feta cheese
No sun dried tomatoes, no mozzarella.

Fresh French bread, sliced, broiled/toasted. Sprinkle with olive oil before toasting. I did not toast with any cheese on the bread as I put the feta in the tomato mixture. I served the tomato mixture chilled and the bread warm.

This was my first bruschetta recipe that I attempted.. and I was very impressed!  (As was my girlfriend.. she asks me to make it quite often.)  It included one of my favorite food combinations; tomato and basil and the balsamic vinegar added a really nice dimension as well.  I second what some of the other reviewers have suggested:  brushing some olive oil or some butter on the bread and browning it lightly under the broiler before adding the topping to it.  Getting a fresh, high quality baguette is ESSENTIAL to making this recipe successful!

text:
I am living in China right now, so ingredients are scarce, but this bruschetta recipe was perfect, even without an oven! Instead of balsamic vinegar, I used some Kraft balsamic vingrette dressing, and about 1 tbsp of olive oil. No plum tomatoes, but sweet regular tomatoes worked fine. I found dried basil still brings out the flavour, but i had to add double the amount than the recipe asks. I toasted the bread instead of put it in the oven and sprinkled parmesan instead of baking it with cheese. It's still a delight though the recipe was simplified. My husband continues to ask for it as his hors d'oeuvre of choice.

text:
I used only what I had on hand...bakery Italian  bread, garden tomatoes, garlic and basil.  No sun-dried tomatoes.  I toasted my bread both sides on the gas grill, topped with the tomato mixture and cheese and returned to the top rack of the grill with the lid closed till the cheese melted.  The next day there was just enough leftover tomato mixture to have 2 toasted slices that I simply topped with the cold mixture and feta cheese for my lunch.  Perhaps because I didn't have the sun-dried tomatoes, the basalmic vinegar was just a bit too predominant after heating but cold it was simply perfect!!  I will make this again and again.  Definitely use fresh basil and I'm going to experiment with a couple different cheeses in the future.  Reviewers that used this as a dip were reading my mind as I was dipping it before assembling the bruschetta.

text:
YUMM!!! Give this one a try! I will say that I didn't think the sun dried tomatoes added much, but I did really like the balsamic vinegar. Also, I'm lazy and didn't shred the cheese, just sliced it real thin and put that on top.

Also, for those of you with OLD/cheap ovens with no broiler setting like me (yes they do exist), just bake in a preheated 400 degree oven, toasting the bread itself for 2 minutes, and then everything for 3-5 minutes. Real easy!

Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I absolutely love this recipe. I have made it numerous times and even my guests love it. The only thing I change besides eye balling the spices is that I bake the Bruschetta in the oven in a ramekin and serve it with a spoon to that each person can serve the amount they want. 

I tend to make a lot and if I were to pre-make all the slices it would be cold before everyone could eat them. The ramekin allows it to stay warm and the cheese gooey.

text:
These were good but there wasn't anything really special about them. It just tasted like typical bruschetta to me, but if that's what you're looking for this recipe will work.  I did find that the mixture was a pretty liquidy so after broiling you must eat immediately or the bread gets soggy.  Would be better for an entrée appetizer than hors d'oeuvres that are left to sit. I would make again but half the recipe and eat immediately.

Made this for a christmas party and at home for new years and everybody at both events loved it!  The sun-dried tomatoes definitely add to it nicely as well as the fresh basil.  I use slices of mozarella instead of shredded to get a nice layer of cheese which also kind of holds the bruschetta on the bread! and instead of chopping tomatoes I add two cans of diced tomatoes.  I also broil just the bread with olive oil on it first to get it nice and crispy.  really fast and easy prep too..love it!

Made this yesterday to snack on during the football game.  Very good!  I first lightly toasted both sides of my baguette slices, then topped with the tomato mixture and a mozzarella/provolone blend and then popped under the broiler just until the cheese had melted. I might try this next time with just fresh tomatoes and omit the sun dried tomatoes.  I think I might like that even better!!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is one of the best bruschettas I've ever eaten.  And I made it!!  I followed the recipe for the tomato mixture exactly as is, except, because of a bountiful tomato crop, I used regular tomatoes instead of romas.  It was still fabulous.  If you do this, just make sure you get rid of some of the juicier parts of the tomatoes - romas are very meaty - so I used very meaty tomatoes and used less (since they are bigger).  I served it on bread rubbed with garlic and olive oil and broiled for just a minute to make them toasty.  No need for cheese.  But next time I may add a little fresh parm on the top.  But its definitely not needed.  Great how it is!!

text:
I made this three times last week for various holiday parties.  I wasn't able to find balsamic vinegar for the first batch and used the top layer of an old balsamic vinaigrette dressing and it actually worked out well.  However, I was able to find the actual vinegar for the next two batches and those did get a better reaction.  I used a chopper for roma tomatoes and hand chopped everything else, following the recipe closely except for a few things.  I did not bake the tomato mixture and instead just baked the sliced bread in the oven with some olive oil brushed on top.  I put the baked bread slices into a chip and dip bowl and presented the cold tomato mixture in the center with some parmesan cheese on top.  Huge hit!

text:
I've made this twice now, and gotten compliments from everyone who ate it. Some even said it was the best bruschetta they've ever had. This will be an hors d'oeuvres staple in our house! The only change I made is that I add a little chopped shallot. Also, I take the baguette slices, dip one side in olive oil, and bake it in the oven until hard. Then when it comes out of the oven, I rub it with a clove of garlic and add the bruchetta on top.

text:
Fantastic!  I made two alterations to make it even easier.  First, I buy crostinis at Whole Foods Market instead of slicing and toasting a baguette.  They are more tasty I think.  Second, I use sundried tomato paste instead of chopped sundried tomatoes.  The flavor gets more evenly distributed, and the mix is a little easier to spread onto the bread.

awesome stuff. i only used fresh tomatoes and it was fine, tons of compliments, and the biggest compliment of all: they were gone in a flash, as fast as i could put them out. have tried two ways: toasted baguette with cheese and let people top with their own tomato mix, and topped with tomato mix and cheese, then toasted. i prefer the first way, because then i can pile the mixture on, but i think the 2nd way works best for an hors 'doevre type serving. made these yesterday for a graduation party, and will make again this weekend for a birthday party-- yum! best with fresh tomatoes and basil, i am just waiting for my tomatoes to set some fruit!! thanks!

city:

country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for the football game this weekend.  I loved it, found it very easy to make, especially now that tomatoes are in season in MN.  I would however not make it again for a football game, as the appetizers tend to sit for longer periods of time, and the bread didn't hold up well.  I would however make this as an appetizer for a dinner party anytime, where it will be eaten immediately.  One of my suggestions would be to toast the baguettes prior to adding the mixture on top, which would make the bread hold up better.  I also didn't have any sun dried tomatoes on hand, so just used more of my own garden tomatoes, but roasted them prior to adding them to the recipe.  This is a great recipe, I would definitely make it again, but I would plan it better to insure I had all the ingredients on hand as some are not staples in my cupboard.

Delish!
This recipe is delicious, I will definitely make this again. I didn't change any ingredients. The sun dried tomatoes make this recipe. I like to stay with fresh ingredients for flavor. I also made this a day before, drain off any juice before serving if you have any. I also grill the bread on a grill pan, I brushed with olive oil, grilled and rubbed with fresh garlic. The garlic melts in the bread when it's still warm. I serve cold with the bread I don't use the mozzarella cheese.

text:
The basic recipe is a good one. I tasted it after letting the tomatoes marinate for a couple of hours and found it lacking something.  I happened to have some dried figs on hand, so I chopped up about 1/4C to 1/2C and added to the tomato mixture, let it marinate for another hour.  I didn't have mozzarella.  Instead, I brushed the bread rounds (I used a ciabatta loaf) with olive oil, toasted them under the broiler, then heaped the tomato mixture on, sprinkled all over with grated parmagianna reggiano and served.  My guests absolutely loved the end product.

text:
This was very tasty.  I really enjoyed the addition of the sun-dried tomatoes, and found myself making sure I got one in every bite.  Next time I'll add a few more.  I eyeballed the oil, and used less than half called for--just enough to give the tomatoes a little sheen.  I also used dried basil, since that's what I had on hand, and omitted the mozzarella, and served on gluten-free crackers instead of bread.  Hated to do both, but am watching the waistline and am gluten sensitive.  It was still very good.  I knocked off one star because it could use a little something, a little extra flavor.  Maybe a bit more balsamic vinegar.  But I am definitely keeping this one to experiment further.  Thanks for a keeper!

Very good considering I am not a huge tomato fan!  Used fresh tomatoes from the garden and omitted the sun-dried tomatoes as I didn't have any.  Subbed fresh mozzarella instead of the shredded.  I accidentally layered backwards with the cheese right on top of the bread then tomatoes on top of cheese, was still good, but I can see how putting the cheese on top is helpful as it will help keep the tomatoes on place when you try to eat it!  Will make again

Great, easy recipe.  I have made it both with and without the sun dried tomatoes and it's great either way. I add capers to give it a little more flavor, but it definitely doesn't need them. Must make it at least a day before serving so the flavors blend, kinda bland if you don't.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious!!  I'm not a big fan of tomato but this was delicious and both the hubby and kids who love tomatoes couldn't get enough of it!  Definitely making this again.

Update: A couple years later I'm still making this recipe and it's still fantastic! Feel free to play with you vinegars, a mix of balsamic and apple cider, or red wine vinegar all bring out nice flavors.  If your using dried basil let the whole mixture sit overnight.  I personally always make this a day ahead, the flavors soak together overnight and taste amazing the next day.  For the dried tomatoes I have never found them in oil in the small town where I live, so boil you dried tomatoes for 3 minutes and voila! you don't notice the difference, again though mine sits overnight.

This is so good!  The first time I make recipes I do it exact to the recipe, and this one did not disappoint.  The only thing I can even think of that may be added is some diced sweet onion.  I may try that, but will definately make this over and over again!  Thanks for a great recipe!
Jan 6, 2012 - I had a craving for these again, so I did a double workout at the gym, came home with a fresh baguette, plum tomatoes and fresh basil.  I am biting into these as I write, these are to good for words!  I now dip my brush into the juice of the tomato mixture, spread it on the bread and brown in 400* oven prior to piling the bruchetta mixture on top.  Today I added some sweet onions finely chopped...yum yum!!

Delicious, but (like most bruschetta) it's best to leave this overnight so that the flavours can really come together. I added more garlic (but I always add more garlic) and I also added a bit of diced red onion. The restaurant I work at adds diced jalapenos as well for an extra kick, so if you like it spicy, I'd go that route!

country:
None
text:
FABULOUS RECIPE!!!!    I made this for a Halloween party and it was a huge success!  I doubled the recipe to make sure I had enough, I ended up with about 2 cups of bruchetta left at the end of the night.  After doubling the recipe I did add a couple extra cloves of garlic.  I made it in the morning, which gave it all day to really set in and let the flavors develop, which made it absolutely wonderful.  I would even suggest making it the night before - it would be perfect the next night!    I used block mozzarella, as suggested by other reviewers, cutting it in 1/8 inch slices.  I placed the mozzarella on the bread and broiled it for a couple of minutes just until the cheese melted.  Then I simply placed everything out and allowed people to put the bruchetta on themselves, it prevented the bread from becoming soggy.    This will definitely go into my normal rotation.

text:
I've made this several times.  Everyone loves it at parties!  The only modificiations I've made is a use a wider loaf of bread than a traditional baguette (the tomatoe mixture seems to slide off the smaller pieces of bread and there is too much of the mixture).  If you have your heart set on using a thinner baguette, buy two of them.  And I buy fresh mozzarella and dice it and mix it right in with the rest of the mixture.  It comes out well and then there isn't the risk of the cheese sliding off the top of the bruschetta in a sheet.  YUM!!!!

Whew, this was stand-out delicious. In effort to use up 5lbs of roma tomatoes I made this recipe alongside another highly rated version off this site. As soon as I tried this, the other "contender" just seemed bland. I made as written and nothing needs tweaking, I may try to add more roma tomatoes to these ingredient amounts (lots of juice in the serving bowl) but am kinda afraid it might diminish the flavor punch. I should say too I can take or leave sundried tomatoes, and balsamic vinegar and I have had some issues in the past. An absolute winner, thanks so much for sharing.

userID:
2843925
Display Name:
JanNoel
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
16
favoritesCount:
41
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/150575.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this last week and I must say the brushetta mixture was very, very good. However, after countless attempts to making the perfect bread using the suggested French baguette, it just never was great. None of the methods did the brushetta mixture justice. Then I finally found it. I used Sara Lee Sheephearders bread. I'm sure any bread like this would work though. I used as many of the end slices as the loaf had (as these slices have a heavy crust). Cut into small to medium size pieces. Sprayed each piece with Pam olive oil spray. Then baked in a 400 degree oven until lightly toasted. Then sprinkled some pieces with shredded mozzarella cheese and some pieces with fresh parmesan cheese. (do not use the canned stuff!) Then back in the oven until melted. While the cheese was melting I put the brushetta mixture in a bowl and into the microwave on high for 2 minutes. Or until warm/hot. Then placed it all on the table, allowing everyone to dish up as much of the mixture on their bread slices. They were absolutely delicious! We all loved this way better then the French baguette bread. (Oh, on the mixture; (1)I did cut the oil down to 1/8 cup. It doesn't need more when/if you use the sun-dried tomatoes packed in oil. (2)I used 3 very large cloves of garlic. Us this much only if you love garlic, like we do. (3)use as much fresh basil as you'd like. You can't go wrong with more! And if you don't have fresh basil, save the recipe until you do! It's an absolute must. My thanks to Lauri

text:
I have made this twice, the first time I did not brush with olive oil and put in oven-BIG MISTAKE, this is a MUST for this recipe.  The 2nd try I got rave reviews, I made them for my sister bday dinner as an appetizer for spaghetti and they were gone in 5 minutes, even the kids scarfed them down. I made a few changes, 1)I used canned petit diced tomatoes with basil and oregeno, so much easier, faster and cheaper! 2)used sun dried tomato spread(pesto) again, easier, fast and cheaper! 3) DEFINITELY brush with olive oil and brown bread first!! 4)I put sliced provolone cheese to "seal" in tomato mixture then topped that with shredded parmesan cheese. These make this recipe much quicker and more cost efficient!!  Will make this part of our regular cycle !!

text:
I've made this recipe at least ten times now and each time it gets nothin' but rave reviews.  Don't over do it on the balsamic, a little bit goes a long way.  As for prep styles, we've done everything from putting it on grilled bread, to putting it on slices and broiling it, to simply spooning it on fresh bread.  You can't go wrong no matter how you slice it.

text:
Made this last night as an appetizer.  I brushed both sides of the banquette with olive oil and broiled them for 1 1/2 - 2 minutes.  I then turned them over and put a piece of fresh mozzarella on and broiled until cheese melted.  Served cold with brushetta on top.  They were good (would rate it a 4).  Today I took the leftovers and put more mozzarella cheese on top & broiled about 4 minutes.  They were so much better eaten hot (thus the 5 rating). In the future I'm going to broil & assemble just how I did yesterday, wait for them to cool & then put more mozzarella on top & put in the fridge until my company arrives - then put them under broiler again and serve hot.

city:

country:

text:
This recipe was great! The fresh tomatoes made this recipe a nice light appetizer that's easy on the stomach, and the other ingredients really made this a very flavorful treat! As another reviewer recommended, I made the tomato mix the night before so the flavors had even more time to blend. Two things were surprising to me: first, I (of course) had to taste the tomato blend before putting it on the bread - and it was so good I may have to make the double tomato mix again as a stand-alone tomato salad. Secondly, and more surprising, I think this may have been even better left over - I just put it back in the oven on broil for a few minutes and the bread, which had soaked up the flavor overnight, crisped right back up! I'd definitely make this again.  Edit: Last night I made this recipe doubled for a party - everyone here in AZ thought it was salsa by looking at it! Haha. But everyone was asking who made it and thought it was delicious. I was very excited to have leftovers.

text:
This has been an instant hit at every party I have served this at.  A few suggestions...when I don't have really good ripe tomatoes available I will substitute with 1 can of chopped tomatoes (Italian style works well) and I will add some chopped grape tomatoes to add some additional texture and flavor.  Make sure you drain the canned tomatoes really well.  I agree with some of the other reviews that using fresh basil is much better than dried.  I have also used the sun dried tomatoes packed in oil and those that are not and both tasted good to me.  I would definitely make ahead to allow the flavors to infuse.  Just a really great recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really great recipe and wished I was able to give it 4.5 stars instead since I think a few changes need to be made.  First, you should really use white balsamic vinegar if you can - the traditional/brown gave it an unappealing colour.  I would also recommend slicing the mozzarella into slices to place atop the bruschetta for melting since the shredded was everywhere and difficult to keep in place.  Even better is if you broil the bread with the cheese atop first and then allow people to spoon as much bruschetta they want atop afterwards (like a dip).  I also diced my sun-dried tomatoes and would recommend trying to get rid of as much oil as possible - the sauce was quite runny as it is.  Other than that, this was a fantastic recipe and I will be making it for a potluck with these changes in mind!

text:
I'm not a huge fan of bruschetta, but this was tasty. Like others, I brushed the pieces of bread with olive oil and put them in the broiler for 2-3 minutes. This helped them from being soggy later. The only changes ingredient-wise that I made were to use multigrain bread and dry sundried tomatoes. I thought the sundried tomatoes in oil might make the mixture too oily when coupled with the olive oil. If I make this again, I will definitely buy mozzarella cheese and slice it myself or pre-sliced mozzarella. Shredded was all I had on hand, and it was a bit of a mess trying to get it to stay on the mounds of tomato.

Display Name:
CMTORIE

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an amazing recipe.  I've gone out to eat with friends and order Bruschetta just to hear "This isn't as good as the Bruschetta you make"  LOL...great compliment!  Anyhow...I make a few small changes.  First of all, since I use sundried tomatoes packed in olive oil I use the olive oil from that to add another layer of depth in the flavor.  I add a few rounds of red onion (I keep the rounds whole so I can pick them out as I don't like onions.)  I add a cup or so of fresh grated parmesean cheese to the tomato mixture.  Then I make it all the day before except I reserve the parmesean that I add and about half of the fresh basil and add it in just before serving.  As per others suggestions I put the mozzerella (or sometimes even provolone so it's real stringy/melty/cheesy) on the sliced bread and toast that under the broiler.  Then people can add their own Bruschetta mixture on top fresh. Easier to feed a crowd that way and ensure it's fresh and not soggy.  FIVE STAR recipe!

I want to give this recipe 10 stars!  It was umbelievable delicious.  This is something I would expect to get in a good restaurant. I have to admit that I was a bit skeptical about the sun dried tomatoes because it did not look appetizing, but WOW, it tastes awesome with the other ingredients. I can't wait to share this appetizer with someone.  Thanks Loll!!!

text:
Absolutely Delicious!  The sun-dried tomatoes really give it a different taste.  I did make a few changes.  I brushed the baguette slices with olive oil and toasted them for a few minutes under the broiler before I topped them with the tomato mixture.  This made the bread not turn soggy.  Instead of using shredded mozzarella, I used slices of fresh mozzarella.  I put a slice on each piece of bread and then put the tomato mixture on top and broiled them for a few minutes.

text:
This is another recipe that I have made multiple times with great success.  I omitted the sun dried tomatoes because I never went through the effort to find a place to buy them.  I also double the amount of bread because I tend to have way too much tomato mixture left over after topping the original amount of bread.  I would not call this a problem though, because extra bruschetta is never a bad thing.  I also like to crack just a little bit of extra pepper on top of the mozzarella to give it a just a little more kick.

Deliciously fresh flavor!  Loved it.  This will be my go-to bruschetta recipe for the future.  I did not broil it. text:
Slight modification. We toasted bread slices under broiler  for about 40 sec, they burn quickly!!. Then flipped for another few seconds. Then put thin slice fresh mospzzerella and again for a few secs under broiler. Then top with tomato mix. No cooking the tomatoes. Yum!

text:
I made this recently for a barbecue with friends, and it was great. I did make a few changes. I seeded the plum tomatoes before chopping them, and let the tomato mixture sit for a couple hours to blend the flavors. I also skipped the cheese and the broiling afterwards. I just put the toasted baguette slices out on the table with the bowl of the tomato mixture, and everyone just helped themselves. It got good reviews from everyone, and I will definitely make it again.

text:
Amazing! I usually don't take the time to do reviews, but this deserved it. Look forward to making these again. On a side note, I had extra tomato mixture left over and didn't want it to go to waste. I used some already cooked chicken strips (I make these when I make a chicken dish because it always a good snack or lunch), wrapped the chicken with havarti cheese, placed in a tortilla, heated, added the tomato mixture and rolled it up. Added bonus this is great over chicken. The flavor was even better after a couple days too. Thanks for sharing :)

userID:
6344651
Display Name:
whomecook
isPro:

followersCount:

4
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/604148.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've never had an appetizer with this sophisticated flavor profile that my big, burly outdoorsy guy friends love so much.  (Their wives are equally amazed). I skip the last couple of steps involving re-broiling with the mozarella because I'm usually taking this to someone elses's house, which makes that completely impractical.  I just make the tomato mixture (chiffonading the basil is KEY) brush the baguette slices with olive oil and broil them under the broiler for exactly 3 minutes. Watch them the whole time or you may burn them.  Then, throw the baguette slices in a plastic bag to transport and then to put in a bowl or on a serving platter once you arrive. Take the tomato mixture in a serving bowl. People get to regulate how much bruschetta goes on their bread and the toasted baguettes are yummy for hours, regardless of temperature.  This is my favorite crowd-pleasing appetizer.  Even kids love it!
Review:
Rating:
5

So this was great - excellent flavor, moist, and much less messy then many bruschettas I've had.

text:
This was DELICIOUS!!! I made it for a dinner party and the plate was completely empty and everyone wanted the recipe! The only thing I did different was to grate fresh parmesean cheese on top- didn't melt mozz) I broiled each side of the baguette for 2 minutes, so both sides were crispy. The balsamic is an absolute must- it makes the whole dish special. Use the sundried tomatoes, even if you don't like them, you will love it all together. I used canned tomatoes (drained THOROUGHLY) and fresh basil is a must too. Will def make again!! Thanks!

text:
Absolutely the BEST bruschetta recipe I've tried! I'm in love! So simple, too, just tedious cutting all the tomatoes. I've made it multiple times for my friends and family, and they just GOBBLE it up! Seriously, don't change anything. I did everything exactly as shown in the recipe. Just make sure to use FRESH BASIL. I cannot emphasize that enough! Fresh or nothing. Dried basil is a waste of space. It makes all the difference. Also, try to go to your grocery store in the morning to get the freshest bread, or get the ready-to-bake one, which is often cheaper.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4240036.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love bruschetta! I halved the baguette lengthwise and crosswise to better hold all the goodness in the toppings. I didn't have any fresh or regular sun-dried tomatoes, but I had smoked sun-dried tomatoes so I used them. I also used fresh buffalo mozzarella and Locatelli romano cheeses. The romano has a sweet nuttiness that holds up to the vinegar well. The only thing I wish I did differently was not having white balsamic vinegar. The aged Modena balsamic vinegar was a tad strong. Oh, and I made the garlic bread in one of those microwave/convection combo ovens at 450°. Thanks for the idea of sun-dried tomatoes! I never thought of them on bruschetta.
Review:
Rating:
5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6078809.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great appetizer. I didn't use Roma tomatoes because I had lots of vine ripened ones. My suggestion is if you use vine ripened tomatoes to chop and then drain them for about 30 mins. in a colander so the mixture isn't so runny.  Maybe it was just me but I felt like the sun dried tomatoes in olive oil was plenty of olive oil. So, I didn't add any more. For sure use fresh basil if possible - makes a big difference - again I didn't use but about 2 tbsp. and felt it was very flavorful. I served these as appetizers to 6 adults and they all loved them. We were off to dinner so I had quite a few left over even after almost everyone had 2 or 3. Some of the guys just wanted to stay and eat the rest and pass on dinner!!

text:
This is a 5 star recipe as is.  I've made it multiple times now and I am never disappointed.  I've read a number of reviews that said it caused the bread to get soggy.  I have started leaving the extra oil out and deseeding the tomatoes before chopping them.  It makes a huge difference.  I've also started using a better quality balsamic vinegar (three leaf) and it's improved the flavor.

text:
I halve the recipe because 6 tomatoes make a lot of bruschetta.  Easy to follow tasty recipe!  Like other reviewers, I toast the bread with the cheese and have people add however much bruschetta they want on top, otherwise, I'd probably make a mess in the oven and have soggy bread to boot.  I used tomatoes on a vine one time and it made it very watery, I would recommend sticking to the plum tomatoes.

text:
I planned on making this tomorrow as an appetizer, but I wanted to try it out beforehand. Big mistake because after making 4 or 5 I had to make the whole loaf of bread. My husband I devoured it and I look forward to making again tomorrow! So delicious. I used Italian seasoned diced tomatoes in a can and I also used the basil from my spice rack. I took the advice of others and brushed the bread with olive oil and baked for 5 minutes on 400, then added the tomato mixture and mozz and baked for another 5. The bread came out perfect! Enough crunch without being too hard. The best bruschetta I've ever tasted.

text:
WOW!! This was terrific. I used some of the oil from the sundried tomato jar in place of the olive oil, and I used about 5 or 6 cloves of roasted garlic. I put everything (except the cheese and the bread) into the food processer and pulsed a few times until it was about the consistency of spaghetti sauce. I refrigerated it overnight and served as a cold dip with fried zucchini and packaged panetini toasts as an appetizer for some guests. They raved over it! I will be making this again, ASAP- and in a much larger quantity! It'd be awesome as a pizza sauce.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/155162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This may be one of the best recipes I've ever gotten from Allrecipes. I made it at the lake for about 6 people who couldn't stop talking about how awesome it was. I mixed the sundried tomatoes, garlic, OO, vinegar, and salt and pepper and let it sit in the fridge overnight. About half-hour before serving, I added the romas and basil. Bake these on a wire-rack, if possible, so the bottom of your toasts stay nice and crispy. While I did use the mozzarella, a family friend has made it using goat cheese and said its even better. This is a huge winner and is great for summer entertaining.

This was great and pretty easy to make for a party - I made the tomato mixture the night before and also sliced the bread the night before.  Day of the party I brushed the bread with garlic butter and toasted in 400 degree oven for about 5 minutes then added the toppings and put back in the oven for another 5 minutes (saved me from having to watch the oven the whole time under the broiler).  I used two cans of petite diced tomatos that I drained well but did use  fresh basil.

I get so many compliments on this one.  I used the ingredients but compiled them different.  I dumped all the ingredients together. The difference: I cubed the cheese into tiny cubes and dumped that in as well.  I let it marinade for a few hours before serving. Toasted some bagettes. Served both side by side and have my guests spoon their bruschetta on the bagettes.  This prevents soggy bread and a fresher tasting appetizer.  Yummy!

This was really really good!! I made the tomato mixture the night before so all the flavors marinated together overnight. I baked a loaf of Coles's garlic bread and when it was almost done I took it out of the oven and topped with the tomato mixture and cheese before putting back in the oven on broil until the cheese melted. I had bruschetta once like this at a restaurant and it was so good! Only thing was though that the bread got a little soggy under the tomatoes. Maybe next time I will broil the bread for a few minutes before adding tomatoes. Still great though, everyone was surprised that I really made it myself!

text:
This was a delicious but best of all extremely easy recipe!  I made these for a Christmas gathering of my Book Club and they were a definite hit.  I did make a few changes by way of what I had in my pantry, suggestions of other reviewers, and one accidental mistake.  I used diced tomatoes, dried basil, instead of adding olive oil to the mixture I used the extra oil from the sundried tomatoes for flavor.  I let this mixture sit in the fridge overnight as someone had suggested.  I did use fresh mozzerella which I think is important.  I also brushed the bread slices with olive oil before putting on the cheese.  Once I had everything layered, I cooked it all together about 4 min. and it was perfectly done.  I will be making these often.  Thank you!!!

text:
Excellent and super easy and quick to make. The bonus is that I was able to use the tomatoes and basil fresh from my garden.  Will make this again and again. I followed a previous reviewer's suggestion and bought the chunk of mozzarella cheese and cut into slices to lay over the top of the mixture (or you can put on the bottom for a more attractive presentation). For those that don't know... you can have your grocer put the french baguette through their slicer and this will save you the step of all that cutting.  It comes out perfectly sliced!

This is great stuff. I use a can of petite diced tomatoes and skip the dried tomatoes. It is more cost of effective and faster this way. Everyone loves it and no one has ever noticed the difference. This is one I like to take to parties. Also, the cheese is unnecessary. If you don't have it on hand, don't worry about it. Make it anyway. It amazing even without it!

I was suprised by how good these were!  My boyfriend can't stand the taste of tomatoes if they're uncooked, so I wasn't how sure he would enjoy these, but he loved 'em! The only thing I would change about the recipe for next time is to leave out the sun-dried tomatoes. They made the mix a little too oily (or it just could have been my imagination after seeing them packed in that oil) and most people ended up picking them off anyway. Otherwise, though, it was a fantastic recipe that I'll definitely be making in the future!  Thanks for sharing!

text:
Awesome bruschetta, I will make this again and again.  I took it to a party last night and not only was the very large plate cleared, everyone wanted the recipe.  I made a few changes... I used more garlic (5 cloves) and vinegar (3T), and I made it the night before and let it sit in the refrigerator.  Probably not necessary but it worked fine and saved time the next day.  My bread was fairly dry so I didn't bothter to bake it without first by itself.  Also - I used sliced cheese instead of shredded, much easier to place on each piece.

text:
I made this last night for a small dinner party and everyone LOVED it!  One of the guests HATES vegetables and ate a ton of this, he even asked for the recipe.  I did the whole thing in my little Cuisinart chopper so that it was not very chunky, and it made it really easy to scoop a spoonful on each piece of bread with no mess.  Doing that also cut out a lot of the time it would have taken to chop all the tomatoes.  I used slices of mozzarella instead of shredded and some of the oil from the sundried tomatoes.  I strained the sundried tomatoes and used whatever oil I got out of that and then used regular olive oil for the rest.  We made 24 slices of bread and there was leftover bruschetta, just to give you an idea of how much this makes.  Enjoy!!

text:
I really liked the fresh tomatoes (from my garden) and basil in this bruschetta, but I would have to tweak it a little next time to suit us.  I think the vinegar overwhelmed the taste of the tomatoes quite a bit, and the bread was soggy from the mixture.  I would decrease the amount of vinegar, and cut the pieces of bread a little thicker and toast both sides.  I think I may keep searching for the perfect recipe...my favorite bruschetta is made by UNO's restauraunts, based out of Chigaco.  MMMMM!!!  Actually, I think it is called Tuscany bread...

I don't entertain very often but when relatives came to town due to a family crisis I knew we needed to bond over food. I went to allrecipes.com and found this recipe.  I followed the recipe as written and was tempted to skip the sun-dried tomatoes. Glad I didn't. They gave a wonderful depth to the recipe.  It was easy to pull together and my family raved about it. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2604492.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this bruschetta recipe so much! And so does everyone I've made it for. The sun-dried tomatoes are the perfect touch. I double the garlic though just since I love garlic, and I use mozzarella slices instead of shredded mozzarella because it stays on top easier and creates a little melty blanket to hold the tomato mixture in place. I try to let the tomato mixture marinate overnight too. Definitely use fresh basil and sun-dried tomatoes packed in oil (rather than dried). Besides cooking it in broiler, it's also great to use the baguette slices and tomato mix in a chips & dip way - it's just as delicious when cold. I've also made it the regular way in the oven, but without the cheese for my boyfriend who is allergic, and he loves it! This recipe is a definite hit.

text:
I've modified this based on other reviews & it's delicious & disappears before my eyes. I use the canned petite tomatoes (drained) unless the Roma are home grown. Fresh basil is a must. I bake a fresh loaf of bread, slice it & brush with olive oil. Bake it for about 5 minutes at 450. Okay, now here is the weird part. I buy chive & onion cream cheese & spread it on the bread & top with the Tomato mixture. You can even use crackers if you're in a pinch or run out of bread.

text:
Truly loved this and it was such a big hit at a party I attended. The only differences I made were definitely adding more seasoning and changed up the topping. So I added more salt and pepper and I added oregano, garlic salt and about a 1/4 of a teaspoon of granulated sugar to bring out the flavor. I refrigerated it tomato base for about two hours, then topped it with the 4 Italian cheese blend that contains mozzarella, asiago, mild cheddar and smoked provolone. It was out of this world and a crowd pleaser! Try it

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-06-17T18:44:22.307
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
13782436
Display Name:
Dee
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thank you so much to the comments on this recipe, because of all of you I have been able to perfect this for my family.  Oh we are loving it with these small changes.
Cut 3-4 Roma's long way, do away with the seeds and any moisture with a spoon.  After all is in the bowl (omit the sun-dried tomatoes and add lots of some fresh thyme to recipe) we only use a couple drips of EVOO and between 1/2 to 1 tsp. balsamic vinegar, add a couple drops of white vinegar (the secret of summer recipes), some S&P and taste, taste, taste.  Let sit in fridge to meld... like 2hrs if you can wait, overnight is perrrrfect.  The salt and vinegar will bring a bit of moisture outta the tomatoes.  Toast bread one side, pull it out and rub with the cut side of 1/2 bulb of garlic, it'll surprise you how it rubs on like melted butter and OMG the smell YUM.  Flip bread and repeat with toasting and rubbing.  Then we cheese the bread with shredded mozz cheese (readily available in my fridge) and broil 1 more time to melt it. Add Cold toppings with a straining spoon as we stand around using hands as plates and rave about how awesome it is!  I plan in the future to try a cheese like feta for even more bite and possibly the (jarred moistened) sun-dried tomatoes.  This is our savior for summer heaven. Also our broiler has a low setting which after making this 4 times in the last 6 days I have found is really handy.  Man that broil high setting cooks FAST.  THANK YOU ALL so VERY VERY much!!!

This was a huge hit with my family. I made the bruschetta in the morning and left in a bowl to the side. I toasted the baguette in the broiler brushed lightly with melted butter and placed them all on a cookie sheet earlier in the morning as well. Then once my family came I put the tomatoe mixture on the bread topped with mozzarella and broiled for 2 minutes. It was unbeleivably easy and delicious!!!!

text:
Wonderful Recipe!  This was a hit at our Halloween party.  I took the advice of others and brushed bread with Olive Oil, then broiled for about 2 min, before adding the tomato mixture.  This kept bread from getting too soggy while sitting out at a party.  I also used cans of petite diced tomatoes instead of fresh as a time saver... the recipe still turned out delicious!  Will make this one again very soon!!

text:
This was...how can I say this...DELICIOUS! I've never had bruschetta before and after this recipe, I can't imagine life without it! I did not have sun dried tomatoes, but I did have fresh from the garden ones and it was exceptional! Next time, I will purchase some sun dried, just to see if I'm missing anything. The balsamic vinegar changes your life. I don't care if you can't stand vinegar DON'T SKIP OUT ON THIS RECIPE! The garlic adds a nice bit to it. I used shredded cheese this time, but I do see how the sliced cheese could make prep easier, and you can get some nice cheesy blanket action going on. Thanks Laurie! This was a life changing recipe for me!

I must say, this is a great recipe. Tomatoes are the stars in flavor.  Good balance of tart and sweetness of fresh plum tomato. If you want to add hearty experience add some fresh avocado, I promise you it goes together like carrots and peas.  1 avocado for every 3 tomatoes. I will start off by saying I love bruschetta; I make it regularly at home, and order it regularly at restaurants.  I did enjoy this recipe, however I still prefer the classic bruschetta to this one.  This one is a little sweeter for my taste.  I am glad I tried it, and my sister liked it a lot, but I most likely will not make it over a more traditional recipe.  Personal preference.

You must chill this overnight, I know it doesn't say to but it's the best.  Everyone raved about this one!  I made this for a girls happy hour party I had.  They all loved it.  I did make changes I used an 1/8 cup of olive oil and an 1/8 cup of the oil from the sun-dried tomatoes.  I also added parmesan cheese to the mix, because it should be there.  Then chilled it over night to congeal all the flavors, and presto instant hit!

Fantastico!  I served these at a cocktail party with a bunch of Italian friends and they loved them.  Love the addition of sun-dried tomatoes.  You definitely have to use fresh basil--I added fresh oregano too.  Like other people mentioned, I lightly toasted the baguette slices before topping with the bruschetta and I put a thick slice of mozarella over each rather than shredded--way easier and not as messy.  Use more garlic

Second time I've made these in 3 days! They are sooooo delicious! I didn't even have sun-dried tomatoes, but they were still really incredible! I did add feta cheese to them though. I crave them all the time now!  One added note- make sure to use FRESH basil, it is truly the reason why these are so wonderful!

text:
Delicious, simple and oh so quick! I toast the bread slices in the toaster before loading them up. Also, I omit the olive oil. I also use parmesan cheese instead of mozzerella sometimes. The sun-dried tomatoes can be omitted if you don't have any. Sometimes I put basil pesto on the toasted bread as a base before adding the tomatoes (marinaded in some balsamic vinegar), basil leaves, pine nuts and cheese.

text:
This recipe is amazingly delicious!  After using sun dried tomatoes packed in oil, I found no need for additional olive oil.  Adding the fresh basil is a must and definitely kicks the flavor up a notch.  I recommend using fresh mozzarella and melting a slice on the bread and adding the mixture on top.  I brought this as an appetizer to a friend's birthday and there was not a single tomato slice left over.

Just made this a few minutes ago...I didn't have half the ingredients, and it turned out just fine! I have to use some powders for the garlic and onion, and didn't have any vinegar at all! text:
Okay, I have to admit, this was a delicious Bruschetta! I made it for my dad and step-mom, and they both LOVED it... personally, I thought it was delicious also, but I felt the sun dried tomatoes were sort of out of place. I cut them into small, diced pieces, and when you bite into the Brushetta, they made it chewy, and taste almost like there was raisins in it. This recipe was delicious, don't get me wrong, but next time I make it, I will leave out the sun dried tomatoes.

country:

text:
We had this for a light dinner, alongside a tossed salad. I liked this, but felt like it was missing something. I did use about half the cheese that it called for and added a little bit of parmesan to the mozzerella. I felt like it needed a lot more basil, and I like the idea of brushing the bread with olive oil first. We love garlic, so I might also double the amount. I only used four tomatoes which was plenty, and I wasn't able to find sun dried tomatoes in oil, so I used dried ones. I do think we'll keep this recipe, but I will definitely be tweaking it. I could barely taste the cheese, so I think I might omit it. No need to add calories if you can't taste it anyway!

text:
You will not want to miss the joy of these amazing appetizers---among the best I've ever tasted! The combo of sun-dried and fresh tomatoes plus all that yummy basil---what can I say? It just about ruined Thanksgiving dinner because we ate so many! Only suggestions: Make sure the bread is sliced to the stated thickness so the filling doesn't seep through. I made the mistake of cutting the bread too thin at first. Second, watch the pan like a hawk while toasting the bread and during broiling. They can burn in a snap!

I thought this recipe was wonderful!  The sun dried tomatoes really add a sweet complexity to it.  I did halve the recipe, but followed the proportions exactly as written.  This was a big hit for our Christmas Eve appetizer - and really, it came together very quickly - about 5-10 min of chopping and 5 min under the broiler and you are all set.  Everyone did agree that the mozzerella cheese doesn't add a whole lot of flavor, and the recipe would be fine without it.  I think it would be great just tossing the tomato topping with some pasta for a quick meal.

YUMMY!  I did take shortcuts as advised by others.  2 cans petite diced tomatoes, and 1/2 of a 9oz jar sundried tomato spread.  Also, as others suggested, I brushed the bread slices with oil and baked @ 400 for 5 min.  Added the tomato mix and cheese and baked 5 more minutes - they were perfect!

text:
delicious!!
I made this the day before I served it at a party and it was a HUGE hit.  I substituted 1/2 cup roasted red peppers for the sun-dried tomatoes, and they added so much to the dish.  I also used one sweet onion finely chopped.  Instead of shredded mozzarella, I used a round of fresh mozzarella, chopped/torn into pieces and mixed with the bruschetta.  I put it in the fridge for about 24 hours and then served it, allowing quests to dish it out.  I made a triple recipe (tripling all of my additions also) and it was gone halfway through the party!  Thanks for the great recipe--I will be making again!!

I also didn't like broiling the bread with the mixture on top, so I just did the bread and put the cold mixture on after.

text:
This brushetta is fabulous.  I am not a sun-dried tomato lover, but I used them in the recipe, and it was terrific.  Absolutely use fresh basil---it is one of the most important ingredients. It is so easy to make this, and it will receive raves. Definitely use a little less oil.  You can buy pre-packaged oven baked Italian toast in the cracker aisle of a supermarket, and make this even easier.  I did not bake them with cheese but merely put the tomato topping on the crackers.  They are scrumptious, but are a bit messy.  Serve with those you know very well, and there will be NONE left over.

text:
Delicious.  I've made this recipe a few times and each time it was devoured.  I make 2 changes to the recipe.  #1 - Instead of adding olive oil, I add the oil from the jar of sundried tomatoes.  Much more flavor.  #2 - Instead of using a baguette, I buy Panetini at Costco (essentially garlic bread crisps) to cut down on time.  Yummy.

text:
This is an AMAZING recipe.  Do not pass it up...it is restaurant quality.  

I normally do not like sun-dried tomatoes but it really does add flavour to an otherwise typical recipe without being overpowering.  It is the "secret" ingredient that sets this recipe apart from all the others.

I finely chopped the sun-dried tomatoes to ensure they were evenly distributed in the mixture.  I accidentally used more garlic than the recipe calls for and it still tasted heavenly.

Wonderful and delicious - I will add it to my regular rotation.

This was terrific!  Like others, I first melted the cheese onto the fresh baguette bread (350F for about 7-10 minutes) and then added the topping at the event.  I added about 1 cup of shredded asiago cheese to the tomato mixture. I really love the taste of garlic, so I increased that to about 6 tsp of chopped garlic in a double recipe! Everyone said it was a winner. A double recipe covers 4 baguettes for a crowd with a little to spare.  Yummy.  Will certainly repeat again!

text:
I took this to a party and it was a big hit; people were going back for thirds and fourths. It was even more delicious the next day. I did not have enough fresh basil, so I used some fresh and some dried, and it was fine. I also chopped the sundried tomatoes. I followed a previous reviewer's suggestion and served the bread slices separately with cheese melted on them. I was glad I did because it was less messy and the tomato mixture was so juicy I think it would have been soggy if assembled beforehand. (If you do this, though, you will probably want to make sure to have extra bread because it is very appealing and people will grab it to eat by itself and with other dishes.) So good, and simple!

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this for an "Italian Dinner Party" appetizer and it was a huge hit.  I lightly toasted the baguette bread first, brushing lightly with EVOO and a little parmesan (green container). I also combined all the ingredients about 2 hours ahead, EXCEPT the romas, I added those just before topping the bread to avoid any discoloration or sogginess. I also added a touch of red onion.  These were enjoyed by all. A must for future gatherings.

I did without the sun dried tomato and it still turned out amazing! My only recommendation is to  toast the bread separate and place around bruschetta mixture. Many italian restaurants serve it this way, also if you want to put cheese on it then melt on some of the sliced bread. My personal favorite, fresh mozzarella.

text:
I love this bruschetta and have made it several times.  I add more garlic--personal preference--and will substitute parmesan cheese when I don't have mozzarella.  Check the broiler often when you make this, though, as some ovens cook more quickly than others and the broiler can quickly burn the cheese and bread if you aren't watching.

STEPHSLUG

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious and easy to make -well, except for all the chopping.  I forgot to get the sun-dried tomatoes and it turned out fine.  I love balsamic vinegar but found that there was too much (perhaps because I didn't have the sun-dried tomatoes.)  I used 2 tablespoons of the olive oil to brush on the bread before broiling and then added the tomatoes topped by parmesan cheese.  It was delicious but the bread was a little too soggy. I think it might be even soggier if I had the sun-dried tomatoes packed in olive oil. In the future I will either use less balsamic vinegar, not brush olive oil on the bread or spread the mixture over 24 slices of bread instead of 12. If you do use mozzarella, you won't need as much as the recipe calls for.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful recipe. Everyone loves this appetizer. 
Made a few changes along the way - did not have sun dried tomatoes, so I doubled up on the campari tomatoes that I had. Now  I always use the Campari. Be sure to deseed the tomatoes, otherwise there will too much moisture (and will be a little bitter). After many trials, we now brush the sides of the bread with garlic infused olive oil before broiling, then melt the cheese on one side. This keeps the bread crisp, and the cheese acts as a barrier for the bruschetta. Always use fresh basil, it just isn't the same without it.

Added the rest of the ingredients (dried basil at first) and let it  marinate together for few hours.  Later, I added fresh chopped basil and large cuts of buffalo mozzarella.  I toasted the bread and the put the tomato mix in a dish and let people pile on what they want.  Rave reviews.

I always use fresh parm and fresh basil (the SO thinks I am becoming a food snob...lol) in bruschetta.

text:
AMAZING! This is so delicious! Truth be told, I never cared for tomatoes until I tried this. Like other people say, you definitely want to use FRESH basil. I like to add a bit of fresh oregano with it. It also helps to brush the bread with a bit of olive oil before broiling. I find it takes a tad longer than 1-2 minutes. You want to be sure the bread is golden crispy before putting the tomato on. I've made this several times. It's a perfect appetizer.

I love this recipe!! I make it every September long weekend at the lake with fresh tomatoes from the garden. It is a huge hit! I don't always use Roma, but if you are using a slicer tomato, just make sure you drain the extra juices from the tomatoes before adding it to the mix. Don't skip on the garlic, in fact, add more is you are a garlic lover like me. This recipe is definitely the best bruschetta recipe.

I followed the recipe with the both of the tomatoes, instead of the vinegar I did a balsamic glaze (2cups balsamic & 1/2 cup brown sugar--let reduce by half). i used feta instead of mozzarella because i food prep and i wasn't sure mixing it in would work well. Last i  baked pita bread (to a crisp) cut into 4ths instead of the bread you should use because i made pita pizzas and had some leftover... Overall, i will probably make it exactly the same next time, i really enjoyed it. (especially the glaze)

It's excellent!  I didn't tweak it. ( I had to use my own sun dried tomatoes packed in olive oil and it was still yummy.)  If you want the best Balsamic Vinegar - that I've ever tasted - google Napa Valley Naturals, and select 'Grand Valley Reserve'  from options on the left of page.  About $7/bottle when ordered by the case - gift some.  It pours like liquid chocolate.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this more than 20 times and have shared this recipe with family members.  It's a hit ALL the time... people stand around the plate and keep eating it, as if it were dinner; they can't get enough of it... A few things: 1- you don't have to use the cheese, although it's amazing with the cheese-it's just as amazing without it; 2- when cutting up the tomatoes I remove the seeds and the bitter pulp (it makes a huge difference) and it makes it less watery; 3- use the best olive oil and balsamic vinegar you can get -  I purchase my olive oil in TJX, Marshall's etc.,  I use a 25 year balsamic (William Sonoma),  totally decadent.  Best recipe ever!

text:
This is the BEST bruschetta recipe! I have made this several times as written and with the following modifications.  If I can't get "fresh" enough tomatoes I have used canned diced. I make the tomato mixture the night before-to let the flavors blend. Per another readers advice. I lightly toast the bread w olive oil.  When I am ready to serve, I melt the mozzarella (when having a large party short on oven space have done this in a microwave) in the oven.  I let my guests top the tomato topping themselves.  Smaller groups I might heat the tomato topping, but I normally make this for a crowd,  Always a success!
