text:
I made this recipe nearly exactly how it is. Since, I grow basil year round (outside in summer; inside in winter), I used FRESH basil; there is no comparison. 

Awesome recipe!! I've been switching over to a more healthier Italian/Mediterranean diet. Do not overheat your olive oil if your looking for the health benefits and flavor. Heat will kill the health beneficial flavonoids and enzymes. That is why First Cold Pressed Extra Virgin Olive Oil is the BEST and the most Expensive. 

I would not change anything except I might add a little Italian Seasoning to the mixture. Yum!

I pulled this recipe based on the ratings and I can see why it rated so high.  It is a fabulous recipe, and I doubt you will have leftovers.  After reading some reviews I changed it up just a bit.  I added 1-2 more cloves of garlic, prepared it the day before and used fresh parmesan instead of the mozzarella only because I made another appetizer that included fresh mozzarella.  Definately use fresh basil as it adds a wonderful flavor.  This recipe is a keeper!

text:
Yum.  This recipe is fabulous just placed on a toasted baguette.  We’re in a heat wave and there is no way I’m turning on my oven. . . but it doesn’t matter. I diagonally slice up a baguette and freeze the slices.  I pull the slices out of the freezer and into the toaster as I need them.  Top with a thin slice of fresh mozzarella and then with the bruschetta. Perfect little snack, healthy and delicious.   I did add a little minced shallot to the recipe – just my personal preference.  Thanks for sharing.

text:
I've never made bruschetta before and this recipe was fairly easy and very good.  As other reviewers suggested, I brushed the oil on the bread and broiled for a couple minutes before adding the rest of the ingredients.  I also used slices of mozzarella instead of shredded so it wouldn't fall off the bread.  Next time to save much time I will buy a can of diced tomoatoes instead of chopping all those.  Great recipe!

userID:

Display Name:
LemonLush

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/630508.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Laurie, you are my son's hero.  Bruschetta is a huge favorite for him and I made this tonight with some leftover French bread that i made yesterday.  I didn't have any sun dried tomatoes, but instead used sun dried tomato pesto... about 3 or 4 TBS.  That really made it pop!  My husband and son even tossed it into their pasta con aglio de olio (pasta with olive oil and garlic - I just learned the real name today!) to use it as a fresh pasta sauce.  There was nothing left!!!  I did tweak just slightly.  Garlic is good at 3 cloves, but don't forget to rub some raw clove on your bread after grilling!  I put my sliced bread on the BBQ and grilled my breads, rubbed raw garlic on them and a quick slash of olive oil to each one, used these for the bruschetta.  Finally, I didn't have mozzerella and didn't want to broil it because I did NOT want soggy bread bottoms.  I skipped the cheese altogether and served the bread on a platter and bruschetta in a bowl.  I had fresh grated parmesana-reggiano on the side if they wanted it. For us, perfection! Thanks for sharing.

This was a good recipe! Loved all the garlic in it - if you're not a garlic lover, I would recommend cutting back to two cloves or even just one. I used white balsamic vinegar instead of regular only because I prefer it. The bruschetta was interesting with the vinegar in it - added a bit of sour to the sweet tomatoes. Altogether a good recipe. I will defintely keep this to make again, perhaps for company.

userID:
1553296
Display Name:
Karen Martin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
141
favoritesCount:
400
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/190.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, this was so great.  I didn't change the recipe, it was great as-is.  I mixed everything up in advance to blend.  Make sure you peel the tomatoes (you can loosen the peel quickly by pouring boiling water over the tomatoes in a bowl).  I added the basil right before serving.  I used the oil from the sun dried tomatoes and added a splash of olive oil to get to 1/4 c.  Update- I made this last night as a dip instead of a prepared app and it was great.  I toasted the bread 5 min at 350, then flipped and topped with a small handful of shredded Italian cheese blend and baked another 5- 7 min to melt/toast.  Cooled the bread then packed it to go.  Served the bruschetta cold on the side with a fork to help drain off some of the water/oil.  Put a little fork full on a prepared toasts and you have a great cold appetizer, plus nothing gets soggy!  Update again - wowza, I just used the leftovers from my last batch as a marinade/topping for chicken and it's FABULOUS!  I marinated chicken breasts in the leftovers for a couple hours, browned the chicken on a grill pan, then moved to a baking dish where I topped each breast with a portion of the bruschetta.  I baked until done, then topped with some mozzarella and parmesan and broiled to brown.  It needs salt if you are using it this way, but made a terrific chicken dish!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I had some french bread that I needed to use up, so what better way than to make bruschetta!  I tried putting a slice of cheese under the tomatoes, a slice on top of the tomatoes, grated on top of the tomatoes, and no cheese at all (for my lactose intolerant roommate).  They all were good! I think I liked the cheese under the tomatoes the best though. I did take out all the liquid and seeds from the tomatoes, then drizzled the left over balsamic/oil mixture over to keep them from becoming too dry, as I don't like my brushetta extremely crunchy.  I want to make this every day!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was VERY good and so simple! It reminded me why I love Italian food again. The balsamic vinegar is just the thing that seperates this bruschetta from many others I've tried. The second time I made it I was trying to make it a little healthier, so I served it on whole grain cocktail bread in olive oil, and it was sooooo good! Next time, I think I'll fry baguette slices in garlic butter. I made some slight adjustments: instead of olive oil, I used pesto, and I used 4 cloves of garlic, but only because I LOVE garlic to death (I would recommend using the 3 cloves unless you want the garlic to have a strong statement). This is a very good recipe, I suggest using this one over any other recipe on this site. Better than the Italian chain-restaurant recipe!

text:
Make the recipe as is !! It really works !!! To make it authentic I used ciabatta bread. Sliced it, brushed the slices of bread lightly with garlic oil, put them under the grill for a few minutes untill crisp. Top with the tomato mix and SLICES of mozzarella (couldn't get grated the first time and the sliced mozzarella turned out GREAT) Fresh Roma tomatoes give a fabulous flavour. This is a no-fail-favourite !!!!

My family RAVED about this recipe. We will be using this again! Followed the recipe exactly, using very juicy tomatoes and the sun-dried tomatoes in oil. text:
This was delicious!  I made it for a work potluck, so I prepared everything the night before, then heated up the bread and added the “toppings” the next day.  I'm sure it would have been better if I had been able to eat it immediately, but it was still very good.  I definitely recommend brushing olive oil on the bread before putting it in the oven - this made the bread soft and full of flavor.  I also followed the other recommendations regarding oil packed tomatoes and fresh ingredients - that really made the difference!

text:
I made this for a dinner party and it went so fast that if I hadn't tasted it before hand, I never would have gotten any!  I omitted the sun-dried tomatoes and just used extra romas, and substituted parm for the mozzarella, toasted breads slightly before serving then added mixture to the top and skipped broiling to keep them from getting soggy. D-lish!  Will be a great hit with any crowd!  I would recommend making it a few hours before hand to allow all the flavors to blend.

text:
Delicious! I've made this bruschetta so many times I've lost count. I use 2 cans of drained diced tomatoes in place of the romas, 1 tbsp olive oil, and add a bit of dried oregano and garlic salt to the mix. To crisp up the toast, I use cooking spray, sprinkle a bit of parmesan and then garlic salt. This recipe would be wonderful even without the little tweaks. I've made this with jarred basil once or twice and it was still very yummy. I highly recommend this recipe!

we made this for a teenage group party and they couldn't stop raving about the "tomato bread!" it was fun and easy. instead of using roma tomatoes, we used grape tomatoes, since i had bought an excess. they added great flavor and color. if you're not used to broiling (like me) keep an eye on the bread slices the whole time! they can burn really quickly. thank you for a great appetizer that's both eye-catching and kid-friendly!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/211523.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe for Bruschetta - but having just come back from living in Tuscany for a few months I wanted to make mine a bit more traditional. Definately use sundried tomatoes packing in oil, tates way better. also double garlic and reduce the oil a bit (because i toast the crostini with oil on it before adding bruschetta you get the extra oil taste) and use HIGH QUALITY olive oil!!! Also i added a dash of dried oregano (not too much) and a little extra fresh basil from my garden. The traditional way is not hot at all, and the cheese is not melted, so i used a ball of fresh ovaline mozzerella i cute into small chunks and also a dash or parmesan. GREAT and DELICIOUS!

My husband loves this recipe and says it's his favorite bruschetta. I usually do not put in the sun dried tomatos and another roma tomato or 2 instead. text:
I let the tomato mix set for about 4 hours. My bread got burnt the first time so you have to watch it closely - but then again, I've never used the broil setting before! Once I got it figured out  the recipe was great! These are best fresh, I let them sit for a couple hours - they were still good but soggy instead of crunchy. So don't make them in advance! Thanks for the great recipe! I usually don't like bruschetta but I really love these!

text:
Easy, tastes wonderful, you can make it ahead, and feeds a lot of people for not much money. Oh did I say it tastes great!?!  Followed recipe to a T.  My only change was brushing the bread with some olive oil, toasting, flip, brush, toast 1-2 minutes then add Bruschetta, then fresh slices of Mozarella - broil.    You could easily use 2 lfs. bread and a huge ball of fresh Moz. to slice. I made this the night before the S.B and it did not get mushy.  We heated up the left overs the next night and had over pasta.  This is a keeper for so many different reasons! Cheers!

text:
This was fabulous.  I have never made bruschetta before but have had it many times, and I have to say this was the best I have ever had.  I made only slight modifications to make it less fattening.  I only used about 3T of olive oil, only used about 1 1/2T of the vinegar, and because I was taking this to a party I toasted the bread ahead of time and skipped the cheese on top since it would have been inconvenient to use the oven.  I also put it on sliced cucumbers and rounds of jicama that I had cut out with a cookie cutter and that worked well too, especially the jicama. YUM!

Display Name:
Diva Dawn
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/110543.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was wonderful.  I didn't use the sundried tomatoes, but the results were still great.  I used half as much olive oil.  I also let the tomato mixture marrinade for about eight hours before I prepared the baguette which really made the taste stand out. I personally thought the taste was even better the next day.  I also found that baking the bread slices brushed with a little olive oil or garlic butter first ensured that I had bread that was crisper and didn't soggy once I added the tomato mixture.  I added one extra step, I canned the bruschetta mixture.  I added the mixture to clean sterile jelly jars and then gave the jars a 15 minute hot water bath.  This mixture was so good that I wanted to preserve the taste of fresh home grown tomatoes because during the winter months the fruits and vegetables just don't taste as good, so this was a good way to preserve the taste.
Review:

5

text:
Very delicious. Turns out great even with modifications. Used 3 different types of heirloom tomatoes, did not use any sun-dried or cheese. Pulsed everything in processor (be careful so it doesn't liquefy!)dumped it in a bowl and served it with toasted baguette slices. Make sure you process the garlic and basil first, to mince them, before adding the rest of the ingredients

text:
Perfect bruschetta recipe!  I did as other reviewers adviced and brushed the bread lightly with olive oil and cooked them for 5 minutes at 400 before adding the topping.  I also added some grated asiago to the cheese topping - just because I LOVE asiago!  The asiago gave it a really interesting and subtle bite.  In addition I added some finely chopped sweet onion to the tomato mixture. The recipe is perfect as is, but I tried the additions on my second time making of it, and I think the changes amped up my personal taste yum factor.

region:

country:
None
text:
Well the recipe was for 12 servings, but 4 in my family polished the whole batch in one siting.  They thought it was wonderful and raved about it and kept asking if there were any left.  

We like it best when I brushed the slices with the excess olive oil mixture and then sprinkled with the grated cheese and then toasted them, butting the tomatoe mixture on top.  The slices were a little soft/mushy toasting them with everything on top.  I processed the fresh basil, basmalic vinegar and garlic in a small chopper before mixing with the other ingredients. The baguette was pretty small and it was a little time consuming brushing the tops, then putting the mixture and the cheese.  I wonder if it would work with a larger diameter loaf of bread or even with a small sourdough loaf.

text:
I had a lot of people ask for this recipe the night I made it.  The only changes that I made is that I didn't put the mozzerella cheese on top, instead I put grated Parmesan cheese inside the tomato mixture.  Also, I didn't serve the tomatoes on top of the bread because I was afraid it would get soggy, so I just served it side by side.  Very good!

text:
This was hands down the best bruschetta that I have ever had!  It was so simple to make but the results were amazing.  I made the topping about 4 hours before a party I was hosting and then right before my guests arrived I spooned the topping onto the bread, added some cheese, and popped them into a 350 degree oven for a few minutes just to melt the cheese.  They were all gone within 10 minutes of putting them on the tray and everyone asked for the recipe.  This is a very simple appetizer that tastes and looks very elegant!  A great addition to your next party!

text:
Wow, this was fantastic! I made my own French bread which definitely helped.  I think letting it sit in the fridge really brought out the taste. I didn't have sun dried ones, so I used more of mine from our garden. I did brush them with a tiny bit of olive oil and put the topping in the bowl for the guests. A lot of bruschettas don't always have cheese on them, so I left it off and it was fine. I'm not big on tomatoes, but this is one great way to eat them. This is a good summer appetizer I will be making again soon. Thanks a ton!
By the way, I used some of the tomatoes in an omelette for my mom and reserved the olive oil/balsamic vinegar part for salad dressing-yum!

Canned sun-dried tomatoes in oil were a little hard to find and very expensive (nearly $5) but they make a BIG difference in the recipe. I had no mozzarella but substituted fresh grated parmesan the first time I made this, and loved the flavor so much that the second time I combined mozzarella and parmesan. This is the best bruschetta I have ever tasted, including in restaurants. Thank you, Loll, for sharing this great recipe!
